displayed_text: Patient: The Erlida? Doctor: The Erlida, yeah. Patient: Two weeks ago I think. Doctor: Two weeks. Okay. Patient: Well, let's see now. Family Member 1: When you came last week? No? Patient: No, I think was the week before and you told me to stop. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Right. I think it's been at least two weeks. Patient: Yeah, at least two weeks. Doctor: Hopefully, it'll you know, flush out some more slowly get better. You know, the more natural thing you should ask her. She's gonna be the expert, you know, like melatonin. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Things like that. Family Member 1: He does try them.

Family Member: I’m L___. Doctor: His wife is L. Same last name? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And she works… Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In your hospital. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: In PT?
FAM Um hum. (pause sending text) Doctor: Your phone will probably ring in thirty seconds. Doctor: Okay, so um… Family Member: And they don’t do any kind of surgery again to clean up margins or do any of that kind of stuff?
DOC That’s what radiation is for. Okay. Doctor: The question now is about starting your hormone shots.

Family Member: Right. Doctor: Once you’ve had a CRYO, we automatically keep the CAT scans that have had CRYO for the person who did the CRYO to read. So he’s the only one who would read them (papers shuffling) Patient: To see what happens, what’s going on. Doctor: Yeah, because the report - Healthcare Professional: It could switch; the report doesn’t say it helped. It didn’t say it was Doctor: No, I agree. Family Member: And to report that you got back. Doctor: Yeah, they didn’t have that perspective. Family Member: Right. Doctor: They were just busy measuring just for the sake of studying and seeing what Family Member: This way it keeps Doctor: Exactly, yeah. They weren’t looking at what’s closer; that was not in there, factored into their thinking about what treatment impact it would have. Patient: Well, you know it’s kind uh; it’s hard to understand.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 5 years (3 years but les: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 5 years (3 years but less than 5 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islande: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

displayed_text: Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: anymore. Which… Patient: Just a second, even with the BET1? Doctor: No. For the BET1 that study will then kick in you’ll be registered to that study and they will give you from that study they will give you the Xtandi and the BET medication. Patient: Because ten thousand dollars a month is not something… Doctor: Well that’s okay. We can find ways around it and getting it covered if we need to. But chances are if you were to go on standard treatment, then yeah we’d have to wait and see what your insurance pays. Sorry about that. Family Member: That’s okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So um I think we should take it one step at a time and keep all our options open. So uh stay with the Xtandi and the Lupron and bring in the BET. And uh I I’m gonna be getting it from Midtown rather from here and they’ll know that? Doctor: Oh well once – what I was going to propose is that I give you the copy of the consent. If you want you can read it and uh if you’re ready to sign today you can, or we can schedule all the testing in anticipation of putting you on the study and all of that downtown and then that same day you can come in and sign the consent and do all the testing necessary. That gives you some time to think it over talk it over before signing. Patient: And you said it would just be a couple days I’d have to be there? Doctor: The two days are the long days. There are other days that you would be coming in and I just… Patient: For how long?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it makes them susceptible when we go back down again. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it’s sort of like not quite a selling point. Doctor: But the potential could be a bonus. I’m hopeful that today your testosterone will come, will be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And your PSA will also be lower. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because part of the PSA going up with the testosterone was just turning on the production number. Patient: Of the testosterone? Doctor: Even if it didn’t make the cancer grow, or, or the cancer grew, whatever, just turning off the, the hormone might turn off the production. So, um, usually I see the PSA drop back down some. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Dr. F_____. Doctor: Dr. F_____ is a radiation doc- Family Member: Oh. Doctor: -so you’ll need a med onc doc like me. Family Member: Ohh, I forgot about that. so doctor connect or somebody up that way. Doctor: See someone up that way. Family Member: Is there even someone up that way even? I mean, I don't know. Doctor: I think so. Family Member: I think Dr. F_____. Doctor: They kind of go out like, yeah, there's somebody that's out there like once a week or once a month, they rotate. Family Member: So they come out and do infusions? Doctor: No, I think the infusion people are there all the time. I think the doctors come out every so often. Family Member: Ohh. Okay.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …so that when you go off on vacation you know what’s gonna happen when you come back. Patient: And I don’t make any airline arrangements from hereon. Doctor: Okay. Alright without checkin’. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, that you know what our treatment plan is. So we can either preferred would be to biopsy before you go so while you’re on vacation we’re working on all of the stuff. And then when you get back we have a plan of either these pills, standard chemo, or chemo on a study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we actually have another study which may or may not be open in time which is a pill plus another pill. The pill is Patient: I’m available all day tomorrow. Doctor: Okay. I will have to work with the group to see what they can do to get that. Patient: Or or I can, I can be s - I can be wherever I need to be at like seven o’clock on Wednesday morning. Doctor: Okay. Okay.

Patient: I could use some. I need that what’s it named renewed, too…my benazepril. Remember you renewed that blood pressure pain medicine for me? Doctor: Okay. Patient: I need that, too. I don’t have a primary care doctor right now. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m ‘ppossed to, ‘pposed to go see one of the Wayne State guys next Thursday. Doctor: Yeah, because one day I’m gonna assign you somebody or something, and then your insurance changed? Patient: No, that one over there, I didn’t. That’s why I told them I didn’t want to come back over there no more. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I didn’t… they didn’t impress me. I mean, they fine (laughs) Doctor: Don’t tell me. They didn’t yell at you enough? Doctor: Okay. Patient: It’s south for you and I’m gonna start going there. Doctor: Okay, but I’ll send it in because I don’t want you to run around with high blood pressure either.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we also have some chemotherapy trials which we potentially could consider if we were ready to do chemotherapy. Um, the um, trial, the trial in the cracks that we have, one is an immune therapy trial. Uh so right now when we get immune therapy, the reason that we use it for a lot of cancers, they haven’t worked so well by itself for prostate cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So one thing we can look at is what if we give two immune therapies versus one. In an earlier study we did we saw more men that it worked in more men. So now we’re doing a bigger study. The down side of that is when we give two immune therapies the toxicity is much worse. So about half of the men I, I would estimate headed to the hospital with toxicity. Patient: Oh, really? Doctor: The main toxicity is really bad diarrhea. Because what these immune therapies are doing is sort of tipping the balance a little bit, trying to get the immune system to start seeing the cancer as foreign. Patient: Ahh. Doctor: But because the cancer is you, if you go too far, your immune system starts to see you as foreign, and we get colitis or pneumonitis, lung inflammation, appetite . So there’s, so it’s a, it’s a balance. It’s promising but the side effects, you know may be a little bit scary. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Uh that probably would also require you to have a certain monitor in your blood, and what that monitor is, uh, some men, particularly if they have been on a lot of hormone treatments, lowering treatments, the cancer evolves and adapts. It starts making this version of uh a receptor for the hormone. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So, I, I, I use this value of kind of a baseball and glove where testosterone is the baseball and the receptor is the glove.

Healthcare Professional: Yep. Doctor: And, she’ll go over all the, the, the other detail, which you’ve already read. You know, this is the opportunity for you to ask me questions and see if there is any reason that you want to abort, uh, or say this is the right way to go. Uh, and, then, I’ll get your medicines written and plan for your hormone shot in two weeks. And, then, we can leave it a little bit up in the air between T_, myself, as to what, uh day per our calendar when you wanna just say, “Okay, this is…” Patient: Well, well, well, we’ll work within that, that four-week window of the month. That has to start with - I just, again, if we, if the advice was to start same day, I would. If you wait four weeks, we will pick a date four weeks out and start then. Doctor: Yeah, and if he had a little bit more flexibility, just again, if we started then, and it ends up on Christmas and the holidays. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: From when I talk to people, first dose of chemo, most of the guys that I talk to, not a huge impact effect with nausea or, or anything. Um, it was the second or third that they really started to feel um - Doctor: In my experience, the first cycle is the hardest in some ways, ‘cuz you just don’t know what to expect. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, when am I gonna feel tired? They told me I’m going to have aches. They told me this, and then if it happens or some of it happens. Uh, so we’re trying to give you. But usually, that first cycle sorta gives you your pattern. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I felt good, and then I felt tired, and then I was really wiped out, I had to sleep a lot that week and then I felt really good and they had to do it again. (laughter) Patient: Where would I find that information?

Family Member: There’s a halo around you that you don’t see, but we do. That’s why we’re here. Doctor: Well thank you. Family Member: Seriously. Family Member: Because you care, that she listens. Doctor: But and I have also have some donor money Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If you know, for medical expenses Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Alright Family Member: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input.

Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip? Patient: Previously we were under the impression that the scans were the good news that they haven’t changed. Doctor: I think that is still true. Okay, so my assessment of these scans are they are stable. Okay. Patient: Uh but the PSA which had been going down turned around last month to point four from one point one but then now it’s at one point four doesn’t sound good. Doctor: No. So obviously… Patient: So am I going off the Xtandi or what? Doctor: Well so we have a few choices okay. One is do we add another medication, because typically people who are sort of resistant to Xtandi. There are a couple of pathways of resistance that we know about now. Okay. One of which is something we called BET1 overexpression. B-E-T okay and you’ll get paperwork on this but. So that pathway there is a BET1 inhibitor that we are testing right now.

Family Member: It’s got the stuff that good for your eyes in it. Doctor: Vitamin E? Family Member: Yeah. Something like that. Patient: I don’t know. I don’t know what it’s got in it. Family Member: Alright. Next time. Doctor: Next time so we can look at it. Family Member: Next time we’ll bring it all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: My daughter-in-law, daughter-in-law works for F____. Doctor: Okay. So this is just to help with eye health? Patient: Well, my macular degeneration. Doctor: Yeah, typically, it’s okay. That works I think okay. I’m talking about the other stuff. You go to GNC.

Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know? Doctor: Well. Family Member: Interact with- Doctor: There’s been a lot of- (Sound Door opens) Family Member: Oh, no. Doctor: Spine and ribs and shoulders. Family Member: Spine, ribs, and shoulder? (pause11sec) Doctor: Yeah. The one, the one thing we see also with, we’ve seen with the testosterone, is something called a flair. Meaning spots are there- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - but we don’t see them very well, and then we give a drug like that, they can get more intense so they show up. And I think these are spots that are, you know, been there for probably a year or two just below the radar. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: It’s just a matter of, you know, we’re seeing them now. Uh, and whether the testosterone helped to see them better, that’s what we see with some other guys. So, uh, but I think certainly there’s enough there that we’ve got to keep- Family Member: Do something else? Yeah.

Patient: No. Um, none at this time. Doctor: Okay. So, what we’ll do is we’ll um we’ll be able to answer some questions over the phone when we call you as well in about a week. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Talk to you about the clinical trials. If you read through this and you say thanks but no thanks, that’s perfectly fine. I’m still going to be your doc and I’m still going to be your oncologist. Um and you have every right you know to turn this down if it’s not right for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But this a reasonable option that um if I was the patient, I would also consider. So I will leave that with you, put that underneath this one. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then uh we will get back in touch with you either later this week- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Or early next week. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And uh-
